description: The function 'create_dual_dot_plot' generates two dot plots side by side, each representing a unique dataset. The plots are color-coded with a randomly selected pair of colors from a predefined list, enhancing visual appeal. This function is designed to facilitate the comparison of two datasets in an educational context.

stimulus_type_specification.title: Available Images: Dual Dot Plots
stimulus_type_specification.description: The 'create_dual_dot_plot' function can draw two dot plots side by side, each representing a unique dataset. The function accepts an instance of the 'DualStatsLinePlot' class as input, which includes two data arrays ('top_data' and 'bottom_data') and two titles. The function is designed to handle up to 10 unique values per dataset. If a dataset includes more than 10 unique values, the function will truncate the data to the first 10 unique values. The function also ensures consistent x-axis range across both plots by considering the overall minimum and maximum values from both datasets. This function is particularly useful in educational settings where students are learning about data visualization, comparison of datasets, or basic statistics.

details: top_data: An array of data to be represented in the top dot plot
bottom_data: An array of data to be represented in the bottom dot plot
top_title: The title for the top dot plot
bottom_title: The title for the bottom dot plot
The function can handle up to 10 unique values per dataset. If a dataset includes more than 10 unique values, the function will truncate the data to the first 10 unique values
The function ensures a consistent x-axis range across both plots by considering the overall minimum and maximum values from both datasets
The function generates two dot plots side by side, each representing a unique dataset
The plots are color-coded with a randomly selected pair of colors from a predefined list
The visual output is influenced by the input data arrays and the selected color pair

educational_standards.description: Display numerical data on dot plots.

Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.

educational_standards.display_name: Using Random Samples to Compare Populations
educational_standards.description: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.
